PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
Upon evidence from within Australia and overseas, the introduction of Plant Variety Rights legislation would not be in Australia's best interests because:
1. Plant genetic resources should remain a public resource;
2. Australia's public plant breeding programmes could be undermined;
3. Such legislation may lead to a reduction in the genetic diversity of commercial varieties;
4. There is reason to fear that choices of seed and other plant propagation materials may be restricted due to the controls placed on their use;
5. Plant Varietal Rights legislation could lead to higher costs for the grower, the consumer, the plant-breeder and the tax-payer;
6. Plant Variety Rights will lead to a further increase in foreign control of Australia's plant genetic resources;
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that Parliament ensure that it recognises the widespread public opposition to PVR and promote alternative means of royalty collection for plant breeders.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —In leading for the Opposition I indicate that the Opposition will support the Bounty (Books) Bill 1986, although in the Committee stage of the consideration of the Bill we propose to advance two amendments. It is probably true to say that books have always received some sort of government subsidy or protection, some form of positive encouragement by way of financial incentive. The first book printed in English by Caxton in 1477 was printed only with assistance in the form of patronage of Margaret of Burgundy. The provision of financial assistance for books has been continued ever since. Support of book production by way of bounty was first notified to the Parliament in May 1969 when the then Minister for Trade and Industry, Mr McEwen, made a ministerial statement indicating that the Government was intending to introduce a system of paying bounty to Australian book manufacturers, pending what was the first inquiry into book production by the then Tariff Board. On that occasion Mr McEwen said:

SPEECH.PARA: This decision was taken because increasing numbers of books are being printed for Australian publishers in overseas countries. The loss of business to Australian printers has caused serious damage to the domestic book printing and binding industry. Employment has fallen significantly and the Government is convinced on the evidence that this trend will continue unless immediate action is taken.

In September 1969 the then Minister for the Interior, Mr Nixon, introduced the first Book Bounty Bill. The amount of bounty paid on books is fairly significant. The table that appears in the latest annual report of the Industries Assistance Commission shows that book bounty is one of the four or five largest bounties paid under all the bounty and subsidy payments made in Australia. TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. A number of the individual payments under the book bounty legislation are significant. For instance, the firm of McPherson's, which is located largely in the electorate of my colleague in the other place, Mr Julian Beale, receives an annual bounty payment in excess of $3m. Griffin Press in South Australia receives a bounty payment in excess of $1.5m. The major publishers of law books and journals receive quite substantial amounts. The figures tabled last week in the annual returns under the book bounty legislation show for instance that Butterworths Pty Ltd received some $160,000, CCH Australia Ltd some $551,000, and the Methuen law book company some $154,000. So substantial payments are made by way of subsidy to publishers of law books and law journals and no doubt make a significant contribution to keeping costs within reason.

SPEECH.PARA: The subject of book bounty and book production in Australia was referred to the Industries Assistance Commission some time ago. On 20 December 1985 the IAC issued its report No. 377. The Commission said in describing the way in which the bounty operates:

In general, all categories of books are bountiable, except periodicals, advertising, Australian directories guides and timetables, books of less than 49 printed pages (with the exception of casebound books, and of text books and children's picture books of 16 pages or more), and books of which less than 1,000 copies are printed. Bounty, where payable, is currently at the rate of 25 per cent of the price (net of bounty) paid or payable to the book manufacturer by the publisher.
The IAC after conducting this quite exhaustive inquiry into the industry made the following recommendations:

The Commission considers that the bounty rate should be reduced to 20 per cent from 1 January 1987. The corresponding rate for paper supplied free of charge by publishers to printers would be sixteen and two-thirds per cent. Bounty eligibility should be extended to Australian directories, guides, street directories, road guides and the like under reference, excluding telephone directories and classified buyers guides. Customs duties on those books to which bounty eligibility is extended should be set at minimum levels.
Customs duties on other books currently dutiable at protective rates should be set at 20 per cent.
I shall come back subsequently to that recommendation about the Customs duty on imported books.

The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) in a Press statement issued on 20 August 1986 indicated the preliminary acceptance of the Industries Assistance Commission's recommendations. Senator Button said that the new scheme would operate from 1 January 1987 until 30 June 1989. The Press statement stated:

While accepting most of the Industries Assistance Commission's recommendations on book production, the Government had decided to reduce the Industries Assistance Commission recommended bounty rate in line with its budget decision to reduce bounties generally and thus reduce expenditure outlays. The new rates should be sufficient to ensure continued local book production following some improvements in local competitiveness as a result of the devaluation of the Australian dollar.

Under the new scheme, eligible books would be paid a bounty of 16 per cent of the printer's net selling price (the selling price less the bounty) from 1 January 1987. Where publishers supplied paper free to printers for production of bountiable books the bounty rate under the new scheme would be 13.8 per cent of the publisher's material cost.

In other words, the Government decided to go even further than the Industries Assistance Commission had recommended in terms of the reduction of the bounty from 25 per cent, beyond the 20 per cent recommended by the Industries Assistance Commission to 16 per cent, and make a similar reduction where publishers were operating on paper which had been supplied free to them. The Budget decision announcing a 20 per cent across the board cut in bounty protection then placed the printing industry in the position of facing a potential double whammy, as it has been described, or in other words a reduction of bounty in line with Industries Assistance Commission recommendations plus a reduction of bounty in line with the Government's across the board decision to reduce the general rate of bounty assistance being provided.

It was perfectly true that the industry looked at the prospect of having a very large reduction, a sudden reduction, to take effect from January 1987, and was certainly very concerned that its economic position would be substantially jeopardised by that two-stage reduction. It made representations to the Government and to the Opposition and made its position known publicly. On 20 November 1986, in response to its complaints, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce put out a further Press release which indicated:

The Government had decided to defer a reduction in the rate of book bounty . . . The reduction was announced on 20 August 1986 following the Government's consideration of the Industries Assistance Commission Report on Book Production.

The deferral has been on the basis that a further cut in the book bounty, on top of the 20 per cent cut in bounties generally, which was announced in the Budget, would cause adjustment problems for the industry . . .

In reaching its decision the Government noted the industry view that a deferral of the cut would bring significant benefits in the form of more printing of books in Australia and additional exports. The cost of deferring the reduction would be about $1.6m in 1986-87.

That is a decision which the Opposition very much welcomes. It is a correct decision and it is now reflected in the legislation. We believe, on that basis, that the legislation is worthy of our support. However, there are now a number of matters dealing with the administration of the bounty and a number of other issues which arise from the second reading speech of the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) on which I seek some further information from the Minister when he is in a position to reply when concluding the debate.

The Minister's second reading speech draws attention to the fact that the Australian Government is not a signatory to the Florence agreement which precludes the imposition of tariffs on books containing educational, scientific or cultural material. The Florence agreement-more properly known as the Agreement on the Importation of Educational, Scientific and Cultural Materials-which was open for signature at Lake Success, New York, on 22 November 1950 and which was subsequently amended by the Nairobi Protocol which was attached to the convention provides generally that there ought to be the freest flow of books and publications of educational, scientific and cultural material. Article 1 of the convention provides:

The contracting States undertake not to apply customs duties or other charges on, or in connection with, the importation of: (a) books, publications and documents, listed in Annex A to this Agreement . . .

It then goes on to deal specifically with internal taxes that may be levied, such as sales tax, value added taxes and so on, but generally it attempts to establish a regime where there is a minimum amount of financial penalty on imported books. A question was asked of the Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones) in the House of Representatives on 14 May 1985 by Mr Peacock. Mr Jones said:
I said that I thought it was unthinkable that a tax on books would be imposed in isolation.

Nevertheless I am concerned about whether the Australian Government has given consideration to becoming a contracting party to the Florence agreement. If it has, what stage have any discussions or considerations reached? If it has not, is there any particular reason why it has decided not to become a signatory to the Florence agreement?

The second point that arises is that I do not believe that the Government has really clearly addressed the question of whether the Industries Assistance Commission was entirely correct in deciding to recommend the extension of the bounty to the production of various guides and directories. Certainly, this has been a vexatious problem by way of definition of what constitutes a guide or directory. There was a very significant case involving a publication by the National Trust in which the application of the bounty or the eligibility for bounty turned upon the question of whether the publication should be classified as a guide, a directory or a book within the traditional meaning of the term `book' which was laid down by a High Court decision in Ambascol Press v. the Director of Posts and Telegraphs (NSW). Therefore, I am anxious to ask the Minister whether the extension to guides and directories is being undertaken in the Act simply because it is too difficult to determine on every occasion what constitutes a guide or directory; or whether this is part of a larger government decision to extend the eligibility across a far greater range of publications.

Thirdly, can the Minister explain why the Government has decided that it will deny the bounty to books published by the Australian Government Publishing Service and books required to be published or printed by State or Territory government printers after 1 January 1987? Although the reason given is that Government publications are usually printed in Australia, and therefore not subject to competition from overseas printers, will this, in fact, lead to a substantial increase in the cost to the public of government publications? In its amendments to the Freedom of Information Act, the Government has already indicated that it is quite unconcerned about making information more costly to members of the public. It increased the charges under the Freedom of Information Act and I have seen a report today showing that the number of inquiries under the Act has fallen substantially in the last year because of the Government's active discouragement of people making use of FOI. I am very concerned about whether the exclusion of government directories and publications from the book bounty legislation will lead to a substantial increase in the cost of these publications and the cost of information to the public, and whether the Government is deliberately setting out on that course.
I am also anxious to ask why the Government has not accepted the IAC report to reduce duties on imported books. The Minister, in his second reading speech, said:
The Government has also decided that import duties on books currently dutiable at a general rate of 25 per cent will remain unchanged.

The Industries Assistance Commission recommended that the rate come down from 25 per cent to 20 per cent. I am anxious to know why the Government has not picked up that IAC recommendation. It is a matter of very considerable importance because one of the negative effects of the devaluation of the Australian dollar has been to increase substantially the cost of books imported into Australia. This has had a devastating effect upon the Australian library system. As a member of the Parliamentary Library Committee I know that we have had evidence presented to us by the Parliamentary Librarian of the enormous impact that will be made on the Library's capacity to purchase books and journals from the United States, the United Kingdom and Europe. As a member of Estimates Committee D, I heard at length from the Librarian of the National Library of Australia about the enormous impact this is having on that library and others in terms of the cost to them of having to face the consequences of the devaluation.

There is a very negative impact upon the process of technology transfer into Australia. Most technology transfer into Australia occurs by way of the purchase of books and journal material. The enormous increase which is taking place in the cost of imported books and journals, which will have a long term negative impact upon our capacity to make the best of technology transfer arrangements, could, in part, have been offset if the Government had decided to accept the IAC recommendation and reduce the duty on imported books from 25 per cent to 20 per cent. I want to know why it is that that was not undertaken.

The next point is that I express a degree of dissatisfaction with the way in which the book bounty is administered by the Department. On 24 March 1986 I obtained from the Australian Customs Service a review of the appeals against decisions to withhold the book bounty. If one looks through those details one sees that in the Butterworths case the Administrative Appeals Tribunal overruled the Customs Service decision and indicated that a work comprising more than one volume may be eligible for bounty. In the Australian National University case a substantial question arose because there had been different printing forms and different binding arrangements. On a run of 1,000 books where 507 copies were hard bound and 493 were bound in soft cover, the Department tried to deny the bounty because the 1,000 books were not bound the same way. The AAT set aside that decision. It also set aside a significant decision involving Pap Printers and Publishers Pty Ltd which went through to the Federal Court. A case involving the National Trust of Australia (New South Wales) went through to the Federal Court where the AAT's decision against the Department was upheld. In a recent case involving an applicant by the name of Hawkins which came before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, the Tribunal said:
. . . the fact that bounty was paid in respect of the books tendered in evidence-
when in fact they may not have been eligible books-
reveals an inconsistency in the administration of the Act which causes us considerable concern.
Elsewhere, the AAT said:
. . . the Department-Mr Holloway, who represented the respondent-acknowledged that the Act had been administered inconsistently . . .
I am concerned that there is a considerable amount of evidence about the quite inconsistent administration of this Act by the Department. I believe that this needs substantial attention.

The last point I raise in terms of seeking information is that the book bounty legislation provides that a bounty will not be paid upon certain types of books which might be classified as pornographic. In October 1979 I raised this matter at some length in the Senate, indicating the extent to which the bounty was then being paid upon pornographic publications. Amendments to the Act were introduced following pressure by the honourable member for Berowra, Dr Harry Edwards, and me on the then coalition Government. Changes were made so that a book could be classified in such a way that, if it had been sought to be imported, it would have fallen foul of the then regulation 4a of the Customs Prohibited Import Regulations and the Attorney-General's Department could have been asked by the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce whether in its opinion a book was classified as prohibited. If that had been the case, the bounty would not have been paid on the book. I asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce on 25 February 1985 the number of books that had been denied bounty under the then section 8 of the old Act in terms of the classification of books. The Minister provided me with some information. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a copy of the question and the answer provided by the Minister on that occasion.

SPEECH.PARA: I have raised six specific questions: The Florence agreement; the extension to guides and directories; the exclusion of government publications; the failure to reduce import duties; the administrative difficulties and inconsistencies within the Department; and the regime in place in relation to prohibited books. Support for this legislation is forthcoming from the Opposition. I indicated at the outset that, to my knowledge, books have always been subject to a degree of government support. Senator Grimes, who shares with me an interest in the activities of that great and lamented Plantagenet king, Richard III, will undoubtedly be aware that even in his time there was considerable support for the book and publishing industry. When Richard's parliament enacted a tariff against all imports he amended the legislation in his own hand to provide that there would be no custom duties on those `bringing into this realm or selling by retail or otherwise any manner of books, written or imprinted' and that there was to be no interference with `the inhabiting within the realm of writers or illustrators, binders or printers of such books'. Continuing that fine tradition established by that very fine monarch, the Opposition is happy to support the book bounty legislation. We will move a couple of minor amendments at the Committee stage. Otherwise, I commend the legislation to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, as you will be aware from the second reading speech of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) on the Bounty (Books) Bill 1986, the Government has decided to retain the bounty assistance to Australian book production for the next three years until 30 June 1989. Although the bounty has been reduced from 25 per cent to 20 per cent of the net selling price, the Government has decided to defer the reduction in bounty rates until the report of the Industries Assistance Commission inquiry into the pulp, paper, paper products and printing industries is delivered in February next year. I congratulate the Government on this move. It allows for better planning than the alternative of having at least four assistance scenarios in less than 12 months, and it is in line with the other well developed industry plans that the Government has already announced for other sectors of manufacturing industry. The other plans include, of course, the steel industry plan, the car industry plan and the heavy engineering package.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian book publishing industry is made up of 30 large producers and 80 small producers. Currently they produce only about 40 per cent of locally published works, and account for only $90m out of a possible $225m worth of books published in Australia. The book sector accounts for about 10 per cent of the manufacturing work force in this sector of the manufacturing industry, but the value added component of the industry is a relatively high 12 per cent. Australians have one of the highest literacy rates in the world and this country is one of the highest per capita buyers of books in the world. The room for expansion is enormous. The effects of the devaluation were expected to lift the locally produced figure to $125m in 1987. In 1987 the book industry is looking for increased production in the order of $50m to $60m which, of course, would create another 400 jobs in the book production industry.

Let there be no doubt that this decision by the Government is a progressive decision. The delay in implementing the cuts in the rate of the bounty will allow those involved in the industry-both the unions and the employers-to investigate the possibility of developing a book industry plan. The Government needs to be congratulated for this, as do the unions and employers, for their willingness to sit down and properly plan this most important industry. Already the participants in the industry have agreed in principle to an outline for such an industry plan. The manufacturers have agreed in principle to reinvest one-third of the moneys received in bounties to improve and modernise plant and equipment. The figures which Senator Puplick cited show the amounts of money that could be reinvested in new plant and machinery in the book publishing and printing field. In return, the unions have agreed to the introduction of new technologies and are prepared to examine working arrangements.

I am confident that, with reasonable and responsible negotiation on both sides, a book industry plan will be developed that will also incorporate agreements on matters such as industrial democracy and occupational health and safety. As I mentioned previously, the room for expansion within the industry is enormous and with a viable book publishing industry plan we can look forward to expansion of our markets, especially into some markets that have not been developed. Our book printing and binding industry should consider entering the Pacific island states and other countries in this part of the world. I believe the Government has made a correct decision. We will await with interest the further IAC report on the whole industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats, like the Opposition, support the Bounty (Books) Bill 1986. As the Senate is aware, the Australian Democrats opposed the overall 20 per cent cut in bounty rates earlier in the week under the Bounty and Subsidy Legislation Amendment Bill. Therefore, support for this legislation is important in terms of the book industry, which would have suffered what has already been termed a double whammy under that legislation-legislation which, at the time, we said was shortsighted and was a deterrent to industry's ability to be able to plan ahead for investment, and to stability in industry generally. We were unsuccessful in our opposition to that general cut with the Opposition paying lip service to our position but not supporting it with its vote.

SPEECH.PARA: We recognise, as does everybody, I think, in this Parliament, the importance of the book industry to Australia, not just in an industrial sense or in an employment sense, but also in a cultural sense. As a relatively small nation, it is very important that we have a viable printing, publishing and binding industry so that our cultural heritage, our own individuality as a nation, is expressed through the print medium. Were it not for a range of support systems and the support of Government for planning and development in the book industry, that viability would certainly be at risk given the possibility of an influx of material from much larger countries such as the United States of America and the United Kingdom, countries which have well and truly been permeated with other aspects of our culture, particularly through the electronic media-television in particular. It is very important that we sustain this industry in Australia. That view has general support.

There are other aspects of this Bill which are encouraging. Certain aspects tidy up the existing legislation. An example of that is the inclusion of Australian guides and directories. This brings me to the point I was making about support for the industry being seen in the light of our own national identity. It is important, too, that there is no double eligibility for imports for both tariff and bounty. At the Committee stage we will be moving an amendment which reflects the concern, which we expressed in the previous bounty legislation this week in this place, for the provision to appeal decisions. I do not wish to say any more other than that because we see this legislation redressing what might have been an enormous difficulty to the book industry, given the decision on general cuts in bounties, we support the legislation and will be moving an amendment at the Committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the few minutes available to me, I want to make a few comments about the Bounty (Books) Bill 1986. This Bill continues the bounty assistance for Australian book production for the next three years to 30 June 1989. In doing so, it replaces the current bounty legislation which terminates on 31 December 1986. It follows the Government's consideration of the Industries Assistance Commission report of December 1985 on book production, the main recommendation of which was that the bounty on eligible books be reduced from 25 per cent to 20 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) said in his second reading speech that the Government has accepted the basic thrust of the recommendations of the IAC, but that it has decided to defer the reduction in bounty rates until it has had time to consider the results of the current IAC inquiry on the pulp, paper and paper products and printing industries. However, the Government has gone ahead with the Budget decision to reduce all bounties by 20 per cent, a decision that was announced in the Budget.

I support the remarks that Senator Puplick made on behalf of the Opposition in this debate. I want to add to those remarks-and this is my main reason for speaking-my concern about the way in which the Government has gone about this legislation and about the example it provides of inconsistency and indecisiveness in government policy making, particularly in the area of industry policy at a time when the thing that we most need in Australia is consistency. We need stability and predictability in decision making if we expect Australia to become a more productive, investment conscious, and employing economy, particularly in the manufacturing sector.

When the Government announced on 20 August its decision to implement the Industries Assistance Commission reports, it had on the preceding day in the Budget announced the 20 per cent cut in bounties. Back on 20 August, when the Minister made his announcement, from which he is now backing away, he knew that there was no logic in making a decision at that time to have an inquiry into the book bounty in isolation from pulp, paper and printing generally. That was all known at the time. The Minister knew on 20 August that the decision announced then-again from which he is backing away in this legislation-doubled the size of the bounty cut in the space of 4 1/2 months. He knew all those things. He knew that it would cause considerable concern in the industry. Yet the Government went ahead on 20 August and announced that decision in relation to the book printing industry. It is an indictment that the Minister took that decision. I accept the validity of his changing that decision. My point is that the decision should never have been made in the first place on 20 August, for all the reasons that he has now given. I make those remarks because the inconsistency and stupidity of much of the approach of the Government to industry policy are of great concern to this side of the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank honourable senators for their support, even for those few nasty remarks just made by Senator Short. I have a few matters to reply to from Senator Puplick's contribution. Senator Puplick asked: `Why did the Government deny the bounty on books published by the Australian Government Publishing Service? Will this increase the cost of government publications?'. As has been said, books published by the AGPS are almost always printed by Australian printers and bounty assistance of course is not required to ensure that they are printed in this country. Whilst under this system there will be some additional cost to the customer department, there will be a corresponding reduction in expenditure on bounty payments by the Government. It is expected that this will balance out.

SPEECH.PARA: As all honourable senators know, the Florence convention requires signatories to remove duties on books, works of art and audio-visual equipment. The Australian Government respects the spirit of the convention with respect to books, but governments of both political persuasions have considered it undesirable to remove protection on audio-visual equipment. Accordingly, governments have felt unable to sign the convention, although, as the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) has made clear in his second reading speech, the Government certainly supports the spirit of the convention with regard to books.

Senator Puplick suggested that the Australian Customs Service has a poor track record in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal relating to the Bounty (Books) Act. As the honourable senator is aware, that Act is administratively an exceedingly complicated piece of legislation. The list of ineligible books under the Act is extensive and the number of administrative decisions required under the Act is very extensive indeed. In view of the number of decisions, the record of the Australian Customs Service before the AAT is pretty good. The few examples noted by the honourable senator, compared with the total number of decisions potentially reviewable, I think are proof of this fact. He also queried why the Government did not reduce duties on imported books in line with the Industries Assistance Commission's recommendation. Book production is only a small part of the printing industry. The assistance to the whole paper and printing industry is currently being reviewed by the IAC. As paper represents a significant input to the book printing industry, the Government considers it appropriate to defer any duty reduction on books until it can consider the industry as a whole. I hope that answers most of the points raised by Senator Puplick. Again I thank honourable senators for their support for the legislation and the speedy passage provided for the Bill.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Evans in his reply seemed to be under the impression-for some reason he thought this was irrelevant to the matter in issue-that the letter from the Human Rights Commission was some sort of working paper prepared by an officer of the Commission. What I want to make perfectly clear for the record is that this was no such thing. This was a view expressed by the Commission itself as is clear in a letter to Senator McIntosh in his capacity as Chairman of a Senate Estimates committee from Mr Thomson. In that letter Mr Thomson says:

At its Meeting . . . held on 26-27 August 1982, the Commission considered and approved a draft reply to correspondence from the Proportional Representation Society of Australia which had written to the Commission expressing the view that the Australian method of electing Members to the House of Representatives is inconsistent with Article 25 of the ICCPR. The draft was prepared by legal staff of the Commission and may, therefore, be said to contain a legal opinion on that question.

It is perfectly clear that although the letter may have been prepared by legal staff of the Commission it was in fact considered and approved by the Commission itself. So this was a decision by the existing Human Rights Commission given at the end of August 1982 and conveyed to Mr Wright, the President of the Proportional Representation Society of Australia, by letter dated 1 September 1982 and signed by Mr Thomson on behalf of the Commission. I have already quoted from that letter and I do not want to waste the time of the Committee today by quoting from it again. I therefore seek leave to have the letter incorporated in Hansard.

The letter read as follows-
Dear Mr Wright,

I refer to your letters of 29 March and 9 May concerning your Society's view that the Australian method of electing members to the House of Representatives is inconsistent with Article 25 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.
Broadly, you seem to be taking issue with the voting process itself, and you then specify three ways in which you believe the electoral system fails to satisfy Article 25.

We have examined the working papers of the international committee that worked on this Covenant to try to find the exact intent of specific words and phrases. These working papers are recorded in the travaux of the 1096th and 1097th meetings of the Third Committee of the Sixteenth Session of the United Nations General Assembly, and in some annexes and agenda to these meetings. I have enclosed photocopies for your information. The Article 23 referred to is the present Article 25 of the Covenant.

From these records, it seems clear that the intention of the United Nations General Assembly was that the final form of the Article should make allowance for different electoral systems in various parts of the world. The provisions of Article 23 (then) should have universal significance and be valid for all countries, regardless of their electoral systems. The choice of electoral systems should be left to individual Governments (see paragraphs 11, 18 and 50, and the Annexes: summary of issues discussed).

The first way in which you say the electoral system fails to meet the requirements of Article 25 is that while sub-paragraph (a) of Article 25 refers to the right of every citizen to take part in the conduct of public affairs, directly or through freely chosen representatives, some voters, namely those who do not vote for the winning candidate, do not have freely chosen representatives.

Discussion about the sub-paragraph concerned the significance of the word ``directly'' which was taken to mean ``unhindered in their right to stand for election or nominate others''. There was concern that there be plurality of political parties, as this was one way of guaranteeing that representation be ``direct''; but no concern was expressed that every voter should have a freely chosen representative.

The question would appear to turn upon the meaning of the phrase ``freely chosen''. Clearly having regard to the nature of an election, this cannot mean that every voter shall be represented by the person of his or her choice. In the Commission's view, that phrase means that the process of choosing a representative shall be unfettered. This is, of course, to a significant extent, secured by the concept of secret ballot as well as by the general electoral process obtaining in Australia. This approach is consistent with the discussion mentioned above concerning the significance of the word ``directly''.

Your second concern was that the words ``universal and equal suffrage'' in sub-paragraph 25 (b) should be taken to mean that each vote should have equal value, and that under the present system of elections, this is not so.

The delegate from Great Britain raised the question of this interpretation (Agenda Item 28, Part 1, Annexes, Tenth Session, Document A/2910, Addendum 1 to 6, Observations by Governments). Great Britain's note stated that ``the reference to `equal suffrage' might be taken to mean conditions which ensure that every vote has equal weight; the fulfilment of such a requirement might involve the institution of some form of proportional representation, as well as, in many countries, some rationalisation of the size of constituencies''. Great Britain therefore suggested as an amendment the deletion of the words ``shall be by universal and equal suffrage''. However, at the 1096th Meeting of the Third Committee, at which suggested amendments were discussed, the British delegation said they would no longer maintain their amendment, if it were made clear that the word ``equal'' did not imply that ``each vote should be guaranteed identical weight by means of some kind of proportional representation in the electoral system. . . . Each vote carried equal weight in the sense that there was only one vote per person and it was cast for a member . . . who had exactly the same rights and duties as any other member'' (para. 9). The point was emphasised again by the delegates of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (para. 44) and France (para. 50). Subsequent voting indicates that the Committee accepted and agreed with that interpretation of the word ``equal''. The Commission, in the light of that discussion, takes a similar view on the meaning of that word.

Your third concern was that the words ``guaranteeing the free expression of the will of the electors'' should be taken to mean that the will of the people should not merely be recorded but also put into effect, and that while the votes of many people are ineffective, this cannot be so.

There was considerable discussion of the issues involved in sub-paragraph 25 (b), and it was held that ``genuine periodic elections'', ``universal and equal suffrage'' and ``secret ballot'' were the elements of genuine elections which in turn guaranteed the free expression of the will of the electors. Discussion was lengthy, without ever raising the inference that ``free expression'' necessarily involved the ``putting into effect'' of the will of the people. (Paragraphs 4, 26, 31, 49, 55, 59, 73 and 70 refer.) This would not appear to be an inappropriate construction to be placed on sub-paragraph 25 (b).

In view of the above, there would not appear to be any inconsistency in terms of your letter between the existing process of voting under electoral legislation in Australia and Article 25 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. Should you wish, however, to take further with the Commission any of the matters discussed above, we should be glad to hear from you.
Yours sincerely,
J. F. THOMSON
Secretary
Mr J. F. H. Wright,
President,
Proportional Representation
Society of Australia,
G.P.O. Box 3058
SYDNEY. N.S.W. 2001.

(i) if the Commission has made arrangements under sub-section 25k (1) for counsel to appear at the inquiry to assist the Commission; or

(iv) there are questions of law or fact common to all members of the class;
(v) the claims of the complainant are typical of the claims of the class;

I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard, as I did with the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Bill 1985, a more detailed explanation in non-technical language of what each of those amendments is about.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
AMENDMENTS (1) AND (2)

These amendments insert into the Racial Discrimination Act definitions of the terms `Federal Court' and `registered organisation'. These terms are used in the new procedural provisions which are proposed to be inserted into the Racial Discrimination Act.
AMENDMENT (3)
This amendment inserts four new clauses into the Bill.
NEW CLAUSES 14 TO 16
The first three of these new clauses are designed to preserve, as far as practicable, the effect of sub-section 24 (2) of the Racial Discrimination Act.

As mentioned, the major thrust of the amendments to be moved today to this Bill is to replace the procedural provisions in the Racial Discrimination Act with provisions modelled on the procedural provisions in the Sex Discrimination Act. It is not intended to make any alteration to the substantive prohibitions on discrimination which appear in the Racial Discrimination Act. Sub-section 24 (2) of the Racial Discrimination Act creates exceptions to two of the substantive prohibitions in the Act. Because sub-section 24 (2) appears within the text of the procedural provisions and since those procedural provisions are to be deleted and replaced, it is necessary to relocate the exceptions.

The first of the exceptions, presently embodied in paragraph 24 (2) (a), provides that a civil proceeding under the Act may not be instituted in respect of an act in relation to accommodation in a dwelling where that accommodation is shared with the person who did the act or a person on whose behalf the act was done or with a relative of either of those persons. That exception is to be preserved through the insertion of a new sub-section (3) at the end of section 12 in the Racial Discrimination Act. The second exception, presently embodied in paragraph 24 (2) (b) of the Act, creates a similar exception in relation to employment. That exception is to be preserved through the new sub-section 15 (5).

It is to be noted that sub-section 24 (2), while excepting the doing of certain acts in relation to private dwellings, does not permit a person to advertise an intention to do such an act. This result is to be preserved through the proposed amendment of section 16 of the Act.

The rationale for this distinction between actions and advertisements is that, while one would not wish to regulate actions that take place in the context of private dwellings, one certainly wants to prevent public advertisements of racist approaches to employment and accommodation. It is one thing to say that what you do in relation to your private dwelling is your own business, but it is quite another thing to allow advertisements which provide that, for example, `No Aboriginals need apply.' Such advertisements are unlawful now, and they should continue to be unlawful.

The new clause 17 in the Bill inserts a new Part III into the Racial Discrimination Act. The purpose of this change is to replace the present complaint handling procedures in the Racial Discrimination Act with provisions modelled on the complaint handling procedures in the Sex Discrimination Act.

The provisions have been debated at length, and passed by the Senate in 1983 during the consideration of the then Sex Discrimination Bill, so I do not propose to go into them in any detail. Briefly, they are as follows.

New sections 21 to 23 provide for the receipt of complaints and their transmission to the Commissioner. New sections 24 to 24e provide for the Commissioner to inquire into complaints. Where necessary, the Commission may seek an interim determination to preserve the status quo between the parties during the inquiry process. This may be necessary where, for example, a complainant in an employment discrimination case is threatened with dismissal. The Commissioner has the power to obtain relevant information and documents and to convene a conference of the parties.

If the Commissioner is unable to resolve the matter by conciliation, there is provision for the matter to be referred to the Commission. Sections 24f and 25z deal with the powers of the Commission to inquire into matters and, if necessary, make determinations in relation to them. A determination, which cannot for constitutional reasons be binding and conclusive upon the parties, may include the finding that the respondent should compensate the complainant in various ways. If necessary, the Commission or the complainant may institute a proceeding in the Federal Court to enforce a determination (section 25za).

The replacement of the procedural provisions in the Racial Discrimination Act is necessary because the present provisions have not proved effective. Presently, the Act provides for the Commissioner for Community Relations to inquire into complaints and to attempt to settle them. If complaints cannot be settled, a certificate may be issued which entitles the complainant to institute proceedings in a court. In practice, the institution of legal proceedings in a court, without any prior statement as to their rights under the Racial Discrimination Act, has proved to be beyond the financial and emotional resources of most complainants. In fact, the 11 years of the Act's operation have seen the issue of only 33 certificates, and the commencement of only one court action. The Commissioner for Community Relations, Mr Jeremy Long, appointed by the Coalition Government in 1981, has recently observed that no complainant under the Racial Discrimination Act has ever succeeded in obtaining a remedy before the courts.

Another compelling reason for the changes to the procedural provisions which are proposed is the administrative efficiencies which can be gained through the procedures being identical in the two major Acts for which the Commission has responsibility.
AMENDMENT (4)
This amendment removes the offence of insulting an officer. It also alters a number of cross-references in the section in line with the new procedural provisions.

The removal of the offence of insulting an officer is consistent with the amendments made by the Opposition, and supported by the Democrats, to the substantive offence provisions of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Bill.
AMENDMENT (5)

The essential purpose of the Racial Discrimination Act is to provide an effective remedy for those who are discriminated against on the grounds of their race. The new procedural provisions are designed to provide the basis for that effective remedy. This amendment inserts offence provisions which are designed to complement the new procedural provisions. Taken together, they ensure that those who seek to obstruct or disrupt the work of the Commissioner or the Commission can be effectively prevented from doing so. Each of the provisions is closely modelled on an equivalent provision in the Sex Discrimination Act.
AMENDMENT (6)

The effect of this amendment is that the maximum term for which the Race Discrimination Commissioner can be appointed is to be extended from 5 years to 7. The longer maximum period of appointment provides a greater opportunity for the Government to obtain the services of a first class Commissioner who might reasonably expect a reasonable term. Such additional flexibility in the appointment of Commissioners does not, of course, deprive the Government of the opportunity to appoint a Commissioner for a shorter term.
AMENDMENT (7)

This amendment removes the current legal aid provision from the Racial Discrimination Act. That provision is to be replaced by two provisions which are embodied in the new procedural provisions. These provisions are clauses 25zb and 25zc.
AMENDMENT (8)

This amendment recasts clause 42 of the Bill to permit the Commission to be constituted by a single member for the purpose of making a determination under the Sex Discrimination Act. The practice of the Human Rights Commission under the Act indicates that three-member panels are often not necessary for less complex matters. The amended provision will enable the President to constitute a determination panel with a single legally qualified member, while at the same time permitting the President to appoint two or more members to a panel in cases that raise major issues or are particularly complex.
AMENDMENT (9)

This amendment will mean that future appointments to the Office of Sex Discrimination Commissioner may be for a maximum period of 7 years. It is being made for the same reasons of increased flexibility that were behind the increase in the maximum term of appointment for the Race Discrimination Commissioner.
AMENDMENTS (10) AND (11)

Clause 31 of the Bill makes the amendments to the Racial Discrimination Act which are set out in the Schedule to the Bill. The amendments are designed to remove instances of sexist language from the Racial Discrimination Act. The replacement of the procedural provisions in the Act has made some of those changes unnecessary and amendments (10) and (11) remove the relevant entries from the Schedule.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) proposed:
That the Bills be now read a third time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have had a lengthy debate on these two Bills, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Bill and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission (Transitional Provisions and Consequential (Amendments) Bill, on two occasions. They were first introduced into this chamber towards the end of last year, nearly 12 months ago, and were debated as part of a Bill of Rights package earlier this year. The Opposition strongly resists the allegations that have been made about filibusters. The Government has well and truly been caught out about the allegations it made about a record time, which has now been proven to be quite false and not supported by any of the statistics of the Senate. Nevertheless, there was a very substantial debate then and we have had another very substantial debate this week on the two Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition has been most concerned to ensure the fullest debate on this matter. We opposed the second reading of these two Bills when they were put to the Senate earlier this year. We remain implacably opposed to them and, of course, we are opposed to the third reading. We will divide and vote on the third reading. We will do so because we want to emphasise, in the clearest and firmest way available to us as Opposition senators, that we believe that the Government is embarking upon a completely wrong course for the future in re-establishing and souping up, so to speak, the existing Human Rights Commission. The Human Rights Commission was set up by the Fraser Government as an experiment in this field and with the view to giving effect to the obligations we incurred when we ratified the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. We put a sunset clause into the legislation, which indicates that we looked at the Commission as an experiment. We believe that it is an experiment that has failed and failed dismally.

Of course, we are not obliged under the International Covenant to have a body such as the Human Rights Commission. Under the terms of the Covenant, Australia, or any other signatory or party to that Covenant, is obliged to take effective action to give meaning to its obligations. As we have always known, and as we knew when we ratified the Covenant, overwhelmingly the laws of Australia, both Federal and State, do observe the rules and obligations of the Covenant. Indeed, the rating of Australia in the world for its observance of human rights is right up in the 90-plus percentage. That is really at the top of world ratings. I suppose we are part of the vast minority of countries in the world which observe those basic standards of human rights. Under our legal and political systems, which we inherited from the United Kingdom, they have evolved. We enjoy them under our present legal and political system, and have done in the past, and we will continue to enjoy them if we observe the time-honoured methods of enforcing those standards in our community. They will be enforced only if we have a free society-one in which there is a free and active democratic system, as we undoubtedly have in this country, and an independent and fearless judiciary. Those are the ways in which we can continue to maintain our system and the ways in which we can continue to observe the obligations that we have assumed under this Covenant.

As we have said, there is clearly a role for conciliation as a method of enforcing a number of these human rights values, such as rules of anti-sex discrimination or anti-racial discrimination. We have legislation on those matters and there are obligations against discrimination in a number of areas. We believe that this legislation has gone far too far by giving the Minister the power to declare categories of discrimination in the future, albeit that, as a result of amendments to this legislation, that will be subject to disallowance by the Parliament. But, as Senator Harradine pointed out so clearly in the debate earlier this week, that is not as effective a method of controlling the Minister as if he had to come to Parliament with amendments to the legislation.

I reiterate only that, despite amendments that may have been made, other amendments that have been made to this legislation in the Committee stage make it even worse from our point of view. We remain extremely suspicious of the Government's intentions as to the composition of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and the appointment of staff. As has been pointed out by Senator Reid, the Commission will be moved from Canberra to Sydney. That will cause a large number of resignations from the existing staff and opportunities for this Government to influence the appointment of new staff. It certainly gives the Government the opportunity to appoint virtually its own Commission. A new President and a new Human Rights Commissioner are to be appointed, and a new Race Discrimination Commissioner will be appointed because the Bill abolishes the present Office of the Commissioner for Community Relations. The Sex Discrimination Commissioner has already been appointed by this Government, and that office is the only continuing one. The only office to be continued is the one appointed by the Government. We can rest assured that this Government will appoint people of its own political sympathies to these new positions. Rumours are rife that jobs for the boys are clearly in contemplation.

We believe that the passage of this legislation is a totally wrong course for Australia to take. We will continue to oppose it. I reiterate that our policy pledges to repeal this legislation and abolish this Commission, if the Senate passes the legislation, as unfortunately it seems hell-bent on doing because of the support of the Australian Democrats. I reiterate our opposition to it and our clear undertaking that on return to government this will be one of the first of a large number of statutory bodies that will be abolished.

DEBATE.TITLE: CHEQUES BILL 1985BILLS OF EXCHANGE AMENDMENT BILL 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 September 1985, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Cheques Bill and the Bills of Exchange Amendment Bill concurrently. The Opposition supports the purposes of both these Bills. The primary purpose of the Bills of Exchange Amendment Bill is to remove from the Bills of Exchange Act the operation it has on cheques, which will now be dealt with in the new Cheques Act. The Bills of Exchange Amendment Bill is, therefore, consequential upon the passage of the Cheques Bill. The Cheques Bill had a very long gestation period. It originated more than 20 years ago when the Manning Committee reviewed the Bills of Exchange Act and recommended that a new Act be passed dealing comprehensively with cheques. These two Bills were introduced into the House of Representatives on 22 May last year and reached the Senate in August of the same year. Now, at last, they are coming on for debate. For those interested in the Bills, it will be appropriate to refer to the second reading speech made then by the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Evans.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, the Opposition agrees with the purposes of these two Bills and will support them. We also agree with the amendments to the Cheques Bill foreshadowed by the Government, which primarily provide protection for the non-bank financial institutions in the handling of cheques and payment orders. The introduction of these amendments justifies the stand taken by the Opposition and the Australian Democrats when the Cheques Bill was introduced last year. Then, the Government urged us to pass the Bill with the promise that it would subsequently look into the problems of the non-bank financial institutions. We obeyed the old rule: When you have them by the ears, their hearts and minds will follow. We refused to pass the Cheques Bill until it was appropriately amended, and the results are before us. I am sure that, if we had done what the Government had wanted and passed the Bill, we would never have seen these amendments.

The amendments fully meet the concerns that the Opposition had with the Cheques Bill in its original form. They are necessary because there has been a tremendous change in financial institutions in the 22 years since the Manning Committee reported. There has been a great expansion not only in the number of banks but also, more importantly, in the growth of the non-bank financial institutions, some of which provide many bank-type services. At this point I should declare an interest to the Senate. I am a director of a building society, but I hasten to say that I will gain no financial benefit from the passage of this Bill or any of its amendments. My involvement with building societies has made me aware of the limitations on desirable building society activities caused by the lack of proper legislation for non-bank financial institutions. My position is, perhaps, comparable to that of a lawyer who presses for improvements in the operation of the legal system, perhaps in the area of legal aid as I know Senator Evans has done. In this place we should use the expertise of our members to the advantage of the community.

I want to talk about the problems of the present lack of proper legislation for payment services for customers of non-bank financial institutions. They affect credit unions as well as building societies. Building societies are operating in a highly competitive financial market. A building society requires a margin of about 3 per cent between the average cost of its funds and the average return it gets from its loans which are, predominantly, home mortgages. The lending rates on mortgages are set by the various State governments and it is obviously desirable that these be kept as low as practicable while, of course, permitting the building societies to remain financially viable. Their tight financial position comes from the fact that these mortgage rates are lower than the rates which investors can get on their funds from deposits with other banks and other financial institutions. The days when little old ladies left their savings in savings banks at derisory rates of interest are well and truly over.

TALK.START.PARA: —Little old people.

—I am corrected by Senator Puplick. If building societies are to attract a substantial proportion of their funds at below the ordinary market rate in today's sophisticated financial climate, they must provide appropriate services to their depositors. Otherwise, there is no way they will attract low interest funds. If they do not, home mortgage rates will go through the roof. In recent years building societies have attempted to attract low interest deposits by providing telephone bill paying services, by the introduction of an industry plastic card called `Cashcard' and the use of an Australia-wide automatic teller machine network. At present there are over one million Cashcards on issue and 450 ATMs installed. Building societies are developing the use of Cashcard to pay bills in large retail businesses such as supermarkets.

SPEECH.PARA: The trouble is that the costs of these services are all high. The operating cost per transaction is more than $2. Any improved payment mechanism that reduces costs to a building society will reduce overall costs and will directly lead to lower interest rates. The use of cheques is the obvious solution. One option is for a building society or credit union to act as agent for a bank, but this has a number of very unsatisfactory features. The name of the bank must be prominently displayed on the cheque and, as the bank is, in practice, a competitor of the building society or credit union, those institutions are being forced to display publicly the name of a competitor. The bank can then gain details of customers who draw large cheques. It is very expensive and difficult for building societies or credit unions to change banks. In fact, the building society or credit union is locked in to a particular bank and the bank can impose its own credit conditions and indemnities.

Finally, the building society or credit union may have significant legal problems. If the building society is issuing cheques as an agent for a bank, the cheques are drawn on the building society's account with the bank. The person drawing the cheque has an account with the building society. The bank, of course, refers to the building society before meeting the payment; but, if the cheque is stopped because of insufficient funds held by the drawer with the building society, the building society may have significant legal problems. It is almost essential, for obvious market reasons, for the building society to put its own name as well as that of the bank on the cheque. The holder of the cheque could sue the building society for the funds, both because of the appearance of the building society's name on the cheque and also because the building society's account with the bank, which has stopped payment of the cheque, would be in funds. This is a very dangerous exposure for a building society or credit union.

Practically speaking, banks are happy for building societies or credit unions to issue cheques as long as it is done in as difficult, expensive and dangerous a way as possible. That is what happens when a building society or credit union issues cheques as an agent for a bank. I do not criticise this attitude of banks. It is very understandable. They, too, are in a highly competitive environment and, if they are given opportunities to hobble competitors, it would be unreasonable to expect them to resist. Our job as legislators is to see that there is a fair go for all the competitors.

What should be done, and what is being done by the amendments foreshadowed by Senator Evans, is that non-bank financial institutions should be able to issue payment orders in their own name and on their own responsibility, and similar protection should be given for all parties to these transactions as applies to cheques. Of course, for these payment orders to be useful there would have to be access to the cheque clearing system, which is a private arrangement among the banks and is not covered in this Bill. Banks admit newcomers to the cheque clearing system and very properly impose a joining fee of perhaps $1m. There is no way they would admit a building society or credit union to the cheque clearing system but the problem could be easily overcome-there would be no difficulty about this-by arranging for a bank to act as an agent to clear a building society's or credit union's payment orders through the cheque clearing system.

It will not be a major problem to change the bank which was clearing the cheques, therefore the building society or credit union would not be locked into a particular bank in the same way as it is now when issuing cheques as an agent for a bank. However, not all building societies or credit unions will wish to, or be suitable to, issue cheques in their own right and for them a continuation of the agency arrangements will be necessary. It will be necessary to protect them from being, as I mentioned before, sued on the instrument.

I am delighted the Government has recognised these problems and has now proposed the appropriate amendments to the Bill, for the problems are here and now for building societies and credit unions. They are issuing cheques here and now as agents for banks-they have to if they want to remain competitive-and they are very vulnerable to being sued, so vulnerable it is difficult to get insurance against it. The competition for low interest deposits is here and now and the need for building societies to issue payment orders is urgent if housing loan interest rates are to be contained. These amendments which Senator Evans has foreshadowed have been endorsed by the Australian Payments System Council which comprises building societies, credit unions, all the major banks, the Treasury and the Reserve Bank.

I have one final matter. This is extremely technical, specialist and complex legislation and it appears to be very indifferently drafted. The text of the amendments was apparently received by the members of the Australian Payments System Council only a few days before the meeting, which did not, in the opinion of some members of the Council, permit adequate consideration of the details of the drafting. I understand some submissions will be made to the Attorney-General on the details of the drafting and if these are proposed they should be incorporated, provided, of course, that they are merely technical modifications and do not affect the basic thrust of the amendments. This legislation has been hanging around for a long time. I think we should get it through now and if any technical defects emerge perhaps they could be adjusted in the next Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill. The Opposition supports the Bill and will support the Committee stage amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support the Cheques Bill 1985 as it will be amended by the Government's amendments which have been circulated. When this legislation came before the Senate this year the Democrats and the Opposition made it clear, as Senator Hamer said, that we wished for some substantial amendments to ensure that major non-banking financial institutions in this country, particularly building societies and credit unions which make up the bulk of that area, would have access to the existing cheque clearance system used by the banks or an acceptable alternative clearance system which would protect and safeguard the rights of customers of those institutions. The Government amendments will give some recognition of the non-banking financial institutions part in the cheque payments system and will provide for a new negotiable instrument called a payment order which will basically be identical to a cheque except it will be drawn on a non-banking financial institution rather than on a bank.

SPEECH.PARA: I notice that Senator Hamer has declared some interest in this issue. I also have an interest as a longstanding member of, and supporter of the founding of, credit unions in Australia. Senator Hamer's comments, by and large, were directed at the building societies. I will add a few similar words with regard to credit unions which have been a major financial institution for many Australians. Many Australians have found that the types of services provided by their local credit unions have been what they require. The credit union to which I belong was the first credit union in Queensland to provide automatic tellers, long before building societies or banks got anywhere near doing so. Credit unions have been at the breaking edge of most of the innovations in offering new financial services to members. In that way they have been able to attract and increase the number of people who wish to do the majority of their financial arrangements with credit unions, outside of those which are almost exclusively within the province of the banks and building societies-the purchase of a home. These people have chosen to do most of their normal financial transactions through their local credit union.

I believe the diversity of these institutions has added competition in the Australian system where there was no effective competition previously. The Government, in terms of its deregulation of the banks, which the Australian Democrats did not support, opened up the system. Before the Bill was introduced, we argued that before proceeding to that deregulation there should have been some reference to our other financial institutions to provide them with a variety of means of competing even more effectively than they have to date with the banks. By these amendments the Government has provided at least some of these opportunities. Credit unions and building societies will no longer be at the mercy of the banks if in fact they wish to provide a comparable facility to cheques to their customers.

Most credit unions currently provide bank cheques and act as agents, as Senator Hamer has already pointed out. Under the legislation they will be able to operate on their own. I expect some rigorous competition in this area. For example, credit unions, by and large, offer free cheques and a much more comprehensive reporting mechanism than the banks have been willing to provide to date. I believe, with this innovation, the credit unions and the building societies will inject even further strenuous competition for the ordinary citizen's dollar, and that is what we are talking about. These amendments are not directed at the major companies in this country or the various people who deal in the broader spectrum of finance; they are directed specifically at the ordinary citizens who deposit money in an account to be able to write cheques and to try to balance their books and to get smaller loans for things which suit them. We welcome the Government's flexibility in being able to propose these amendments. We believe that this minor but significant movement to break the monopoly of banks will be only to the good of the people of this country.

It has taken us another 15 years to move to the extent that we have. I think the enormity of this achievement ought not, accordingly, go unremarked. I thank the Senate.

``Division 2-Presentment of payment orders
Due presentment of payment order defined

``96i. (1) Subject to sub-section (2), a payment order is duly presented for payment if a demand for payment of the payment order is made, in accordance with section 96j or 96k, on the drawee non-bank financial institution by or on behalf of the holder.

Presentment of payment order by financial institution

``96j. (1) A financial institution (in this section referred to as the `collecting financial institution') may, on behalf of a customer, another financial institution or otherwise, present a payment order for payment by making a demand for payment of the payment order on the drawee non-bank financial institution at-
(a) the proper place in relation to the payment order; or

at a reasonable hour on a day on which the drawee non-bank financial institution is open for business at the place at which the demand is made.

are specified in the demand or are readily ascertainable by the drawee non-bank financial institution from the demand.

``96q. (1) Where-
(a) a payment order is duly presented for payment by exhibiting the payment order to the drawee non-bank financial institution; and

The amendments were the subject of a good deal of discussion at the second reading stage. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a plain English explanatory account of what these amendments are all about. Essentially, they enable customers of non-bank financial institutions to issue a new instrument to be called a payment order which will be similar to a cheque, except that it will be drawn on a customer's account, not with a bank, but with a non-bank. That is what they are essentially about. There are many other lesser provisions, but primarily they are directed to that objective.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
The Government is moving amendments to the Cheques Bill 1985 to:

(i) enable customers of non-bank financial institutions (non-banks) to issue a new instrument to be called a `payment order' which will be similar to a cheque, except that it will be drawn on a customer's account with a non-bank;
(ii) transfer liability on so called `agency' cheques from non-banks to their customers and to protect non-bank customers who use these `agency' cheques;

(iii) extend protections afforded banks collecting cheques to non-banks performing that function and to impose a duty on non-banks to ensure prompt presentment of cheques lodged with them for collection on behalf of their customers; and
(iv) clarify some provisions presently contained in the Cheques Bill.

For the most part, these amendments implement recommendations of the Australian Payments System Council which was established by the Government to examine the most desirable means by which non-banks could gain access to the payment system.
(1) Payment orders (cls 96e to Q)

These amendments provide for a new negotiable instrument to be called a payment order which would be identical, in all significant respects, to a cheque except that it would be drawn on a non-bank rather than a bank and would bear the words `payment order' across it.
Non-banks have for some time been anxious, for obvious marketing reasons, to be able to issue their own paper on the same basis that banks issue cheques.

Proposed clauses 96e to Q, together with the Schedule to be inserted, provide for payment orders and regulate their use in the same manner as cheques are currently regulated in the Bill. This would mean that non-bank customers drawing these payment orders would enjoy similar rights and protections as apply to cheques. Likewise, non-banks would be under the same duties and have the same protections as banks using cheques.

It should be noted, however, that the amendments do not confer on non-banks issuing payment orders direct access to the cheque clearing system. As with `agency' cheques at present, non-banks would need to negotiate commercial arrangements with banks to clear their orders unless they establish their own clearing house for such orders.

A definition of `non-bank financial institution' is being inserted in the Bill for the purposes of the `agency' cheque and payment order provisions. `Non-bank financial institution' will be defined to mean a building society or credit union that is a registered corporation within the meaning of the Financial Corporations Act 1974, or any other registered corporation that is prescribed or included in a class of registered corporations, that is prescribed.

The definition of non-bank financial institution has been drafted to ensure that building societies and credit unions are subject to the proposed new provisions of the Bill. It has been those two groups of institutions which, to date, have been pressing, through the Australian Payments System Council, for legislative protections to enhance their access to the domestic payments system.

In addition, the definition allows for other institutions, or groups of institutions, wishing at some later stage to gain the benefits of the protections included in the new provisions to be prescribed. Since responsibility for maintaining stability and public confidence in the domestic payments system lies with the Treasurer, it is envisaged that he would play a role in the determination of which institutions should be prescribed and thus which institutions should participate in the payments system.
(2) Agency cheques (cl 96d)

The amendment dealing with `agency' cheques (ie cheques drawn by a non-bank on its own bank and signed by the non-bank customer) is designed to overcome difficulties which currently exist with the use of `agency' cheques:
From the point of view of non-banks, `agency' cheques suffer from the defect that, as the drawer of such cheques, non-banks may be liable to a payee/holder in the event of dishonour or countermand.

From the point of view of customers, `agency' cheques are unsatisfactory in that there is effectively no banker/customer relationship established between the bank and the customer or possibly even the NBFI and the customer. Hence some of the protections available to bank customers are not presently applicable in respect of `agency' cheques.

Proposed clause 96d is therefore designed to overcome these defects by ensuring that non-bank customers using `agency' cheques have similar rights as drawers of cheques in relation to their non-bank. As well the liability on `agency' cheques of non-banks as drawers will be transferred to their customers as regards holders or indorsers of those cheques.
(3) Non-banks collecting cheques (duties and protections) (cls 96a to c)
Proposed clauses 96a, 96b and 96c deal with the processing of cheques lodged with non-banks by their customers. The clauses will:
(a) impose on non-banks substantially similar obligations to those which banks have under clause 66 of the Bill to holders of cheques who lodge cheques with banks for collection (96a), and
(b) provide protection to non-banks when cheques are lodged with them by their customers along the lines of that conferred on banks under clause 95 (96b and c)

These new provisions reflect the Government's view that it is appropriate for non-banks to enjoy the same protections, and be under the same obligations, as banks when they are performing the same function.
Summary

The overall effect of this comprehensive package of amendments would be to place non-banks and their customers, whether using `agency' cheques or payment orders, in a similar position to banks and their customers who use `ordinary' cheques.

It is expected that the legislation will come into operation by 1 July next year. Amendments to the Commonwealth Bank Accounts Debits Tax Administration Act 1982 will be required to be in place by then to ensure that payment orders are treated in the same manner as cheques for taxation purposes. This legislation is expected to be introduced early next year.
